segments.text: There's a tape that's supposed to ring on this thing and tell us when we're out of time, but the truth of the matter is the damn thing doesn't do it.
And so I got to be careful because I don't want to lose anything.
I like, you know, the first series of questions really have to do with how did you develop an interest in oceanography?
All right.
That is undergraduate and graduate.
In general here, you are going to be asking me questions, and then I...
I'm going to be asking you questions and letting you answer them, and sometimes I'm going to let you wandering off all the way.
That's what I was really wondering about.
So basically, you start off asking me questions, and you hope there's a fair amount of wonder.
Yeah, right.
All right.
What was your early training in?
You were trained as a physicist, right?
I was trained as a physicist.
And how did you develop your interest in physics?
Well, I guess I was just interested in things, fooled around with automobiles and motorcycles a little bit.
And the telephone company did a lot of us a great favor by having a junk pile that we were free to
use and exploit.
Uh, high school, I was, I was brought up in, uh, born and brought up in Garrettsville, Ohio, a little south of Cleveland.
Uh, very fortunate in having a very pleasant, instructive family, exceedingly good teachers in school.
In, uh, college, I went to Hiram College, which was, uh,

four miles away during depression lived at home did a worked for basically for many years and summers and spare time etc on for a fellow who ran a local greenhouse and who also he and another fellow did contracting so I got kind of a wide experience of
utilizing your hands and doing an extremely large variety of peon-like jobs, which was probably very good for me.
Hiram College was small, with a population of about 400 when I was there.
Most people knew nearly everybody else.
a building about the size of this present building we're in, the Oceanographic Institution's first building.
It housed all of the science departments, and we were very fortunate that we had exceedingly good one-man departments.
From the time you were a sophomore on, if you were serious about your business, you were treated like a graduate student.
The sophomores taught laboratories for the freshmen,
juniors taught laboratories for the Southmores and the seniors taught laboratories for the juniors.
And I also had a WPA job to build instrumentation for exhibits and lectures and things like this.
The graduates for
When I was considering graduate school, I didn't really see how I could swing it.
As the professor said, my grades were good enough in some of my sciences.
And my grades in some of the other things were a little too abominable to make the grade in the Depression when the competition was so tough.
Happily for me,
a classmate of mine who had a graduate assistantship at Lehigh University.
At the very last moment, he got an opportunity to go to a better job, and he suggested me, and so in about the last week of summer, I got an opportunity to go to Lehigh University in Pennsylvania.
This was...
There I had the very good fortune to, arriving a couple of days early to get my feet on the ground, I was put in an office with Morris Ewing, who was assistant professor there at that time.
He was busily at work on geophysical work, preparing a crystal clock for gravity at sea measurements in submarines.
And after about two minutes of pleasantry, he put me to work in a profession.
And he turned out to be a pretty good slave driver for pretty much not only the next four years, but much of the next decade.
I didn't know he'd ever been at Lehigh.
Yes.
What did he teach at Lehigh?
Well, he taught mostly sophomore physics.
And then he taught geophysics.
He did a wide variety of really small things in working with some of the mining people, Bethlehem Steel, in geophysics, some electrical work, some work
sound vibrations in the ice, things like this.
And he attracted the attention in about 35, something like this, or 34, of Dr. Richard Field, who was a professor of geology at Princeton and is certainly one of the great heroes of

of modern geology and certainly plate tectonics, because he and William Bowie from the Coaster Bay were leaders in the feeling that somehow or other geology was getting on a plateau, and classical geologists working on land-borne geology.

we're sort of reaching a law diminishing returns, and because most of the Earth's surface was water, we knew so little about the geology at sea that it was probable that the next big steps would be in the sea.
So as I sometimes put it, that although Dick Field was considered to be a funny person by

by many even before he had his automobile accident and certainly very funny after that he was a true fundamentalist and he had the vision to both see and to encourage some few young whippersnapper professors like Harry Hess at Princeton and Morris Ewing at Lehigh that the real future of geology lay in the sea and
If they looked in that direction, he would back them to the hilt with everything that he could, and they might make a reputation for themselves.
It certainly turned out to be true.
At the time I arrived, he and Dr. Bowie from the Coast Guard had been very effective in getting US submarines
follow the path of the Dutch submarine Navy when they supported venting Midas and making gravity measurements at sea.
The field had talked the Bell Telephone Laboratories into making the first of the crystal clocks.
Incidentally, is this a crystal clock?
Watch.
Don't know.
Well.
It doesn't make any noise.
What it is is a 695 Timex.
That's my bad ear.
But in this day and age of crystal watches that run for a year on your wrist, it is interesting to think about this clock, which was produced in about 1935.
It was the first of the portable crystals.
It had 180 volts of lead acid B batteries and was about half a relay rack.
This turned out to be, for over a decade, one of the great timepieces of geophysics because it could be moved around at sea and in submarines.
My first job was in sort of looking at the system was I thought perhaps
Well, excuse me.
One of the difficulties they had was the whirling wheel, the rotor of the machine, was viewed by a little crude stroboscope, which was triggered by WWV signals over the radio.
And presumably, if there wasn't any static, every second you would get a pop and you could read the thing very carefully, about a thousandth of a second.
When the static was going strong, it popped so often that it was hard to see anything but a blur.

And having been interested in photography and taking advantage of the nonlinear characteristics of some of the curves having to do with illumination and film density, we built up a little integrating system and took pictures of it.
So that was how I got in.
how I got in oceanography.
The work at Lehigh was primarily the normal geophysical graduate work with the addition of about six, administering about six laboratories a week for sophomores, which was probably good for the
but it took up a lot of time.
It was a tremendous amount of extracurricular time spent on working on equipment.

This was, I suppose in one respect, I made the mistake of getting so interested in research that I didn't do very well with my classwork, which I'm not sure in retrospect whether this was good or bad, but it's the way it was.
The principal thing we worked on at Lehigh that I worked on with Ewing was the geophysical measurement of trying to see how deep the sediments were.
It was basically how much mud is there on the bottom of the ocean.
And it turned out, years later, we found out there was surprisingly little mud.
That was one of the important, turned out to be one of the important clues on plate tectonics, that why weren't there more sediments in the ocean, and particularly near the center of the ocean.
But anyhow, back at that time, it was trying to get some apparatus going.
We both practiced and tried to get data
by doing seismic work along the continental shelf from the outcrops in the Appalachians out to the edge of the ocean.
A strong coworker there was John Lamar Warzel, who was an undergraduate at the same time I was a graduate student.
He was one of several very smart, very hardworking, very cantankerous
students that ended up with versatility and toughness to keep going at the system.
We built nearly all of our own apparatus in deep water work.
Excuse me, I want to go back to the work on land.
For about

A year and a half, or over about a two-year period, we intermittently did this shore work with about five lines of stations from the outcrops down to the beach, mostly across the state of New Jersey, although some in New England.
One had to learn a certain amount of politics because you tended to drill your shot holes
at the edge of the highway.
So if the highwayman came along, you said you thought you were on the man's property.
And if a farmer came along, you said you thought you were on the highway.
And then after the dynamite blew up, why, then you folded your tent and left as quickly as you could.
But there was a great deal of work with explosives at that time.
and this was transformed soon into work at sea.

But in this work on land, one interesting aspect of it was we'd go out for extremely long weekends, and on Sunday night when we came back, we would, when possible, try and stop off at Princeton and see Richard Field, who was interested in how things were going.
I want to emphasize again what a
What a great influence he had, certainly on people like Morris Ewing and also on junior people such as myself.
Along about 1937, Ewing got a grant from the Geological Society of America to do
deepwater geophysical work at sea.
This work was going to be done in cooperation with the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution and their ship Atlantis.
For the next three years, we had about 10 days or two weeks, the tail end of each summer, to utilize the ship in conjunction with other people to test out our apparatus and get some measurements.
I will outline the approach a little bit because I think that is an important part, has played an important part in certainly the way I've looked at oceanography and equipment.
The first way was to copy pretty much what they were doing at sea.
We got a piece of an old cannon barrel for an instrument case.
We had a string of four geophones and three bombs
We built all the apparatus that went into them, including the geophones.
I took them to sea and used them for two summers.
Amongst other things, the first year we did not know whether explosives would go off on the bottom of the ocean.
DuPont had
suggested they might not, so we built pressure cases for them.
The second year, we tried TNT and making TNT, we took granulated TNT, sent it down to the bottom in rubber bags so it would compress, then we drilled a hole in it
for the blasting caps, and the next day we would put our blasting caps in it and put it back and tighten up the rubber balloons and use our TNT exposed to full sea pressure.
It seemed to function all right.
However, the general problem of laying out a piece of apparatus nearly a mile long, half a mile long on the bottom of the ocean,
And keeping it oriented and then keeping this sensitive apparatus so that it wasn't jerked on by this half-inch steel cable that supported it all was a little much, and we knew it.
I think one of the more interesting days of my life was one Sunday night after reading the New York Times about...

Jacques, about Auguste Picard's bathyscaphe, where they used gasoline to float the bathyscaphe up and down, we came to the conclusion that perhaps this was the way to lower our apparatus to the bottom.
And in fact, we wrote up a paper on this and proposed this as deep sea instruments without wires or cables.

One Sunday night, we thought about this very seriously, in fact, so seriously that we decided to junk a two-year-old program that had a fantastic amount of work already into it on the grounds that it just couldn't stand up to a free instrument system.
So we started building apparatus
where each recorder, each bomb was completely separate with its own time clock, which was furnished by the Hamlin Watch Company.
Several points about this kind of work, which I believe were important to the future of individuals involved in oceanography.
One, it was starting at the bottom of the ocean.
I'd been in oceanography for three years before I had much of anything to do with any equipment or ideas and so forth, which were meant to be used at water depths shallower than two miles.
And as a result, you got thinking of the bottom of the ocean with the standard depth, and all other depths were less than standard.
drove one rather early to think much more about pressurized, about pressure vessels and also techniques in which you do not need to put things in pressure vessels.
When we first needed batteries to run the light through a deep sea camera, just the thought of putting ordinary
dry cell batteries into a container bothered us both from the standpoint of cost and also from the standpoint of weight.
So we couldn't see any reason why chemically a storage battery shouldn't work as well exposed to sea pressure as not.
By this time, we had a 14-inch shell, which we'd gotten from the Army and installed.
And this could be operated at pressures up to 12,000 to 15,000 PSI, or about 10,000 PSI, which we did.
Nearly all that work was done at night because it was so close to the breaking point of the shell.
And it was installed just below the office of the chairman of the department.
And we thought if there was going to be an accident, it better be at night.

It turned out, of course, that not only was the storage battery happy working at pressure, but it actually seemed to, if anything, prefer the temperatures and pressures at the bottom of the ocean over being jostled around in your automobile.
This technique was
in one way or another, was used in a variety of other ways.
I think the important thing here is that we, very early on, we maintained respect, but we lost any particular fear for pressures in the bottom of the ocean.
Because as Percy Bridgman said in his book on high pressures, that his book was not about pressures like 10,000 psi.
His book was about high pressures.

And this is important because altogether too many people still do think of the pressures in the bottom of the ocean as being high when actually they're low compared to the strength of a wide range of commonly used materials.
And I think the important thing about the bottom of the ocean is be careful but be optimistic.
The...
Seismic at sea work was continued rather falteringly.
A tremendous amount of effort went into building the apparatus, and it didn't get very much usage, but it got a few numbers during the next four years.
Lately, Ted Bullard, in describing some of this work,
said that he was amazed that Ewing was willing to draw so many conclusions from so little data.
But he realized that A, that was all the data we had, and B, that was Ewing.
Incidentally, Ted Bullard did come over and go out to see on some of the measurements.
Another important part in this era was the development of underwater cameras, which we did a little bit.
First was done up in the Gulf of Maine with a camera we put together over a weekend because it seemed so ridiculous to go to sea and not take pictures.
We bought a $12 Argus, a
used a pressure case that was made out of a test tube we had that was three feet long and about six inches in diameter.
And while this was able to float by itself, we fastened a piece of string or what the fishermen called cod line to it so we could operate it at night and not lose it.
When you don't have much money, you have to be much more fundamental.

So that we didn't lose this thing, we had a ground rule that no one on the camera could wear any gloves because the string wasn't terribly strong, but it was very fine, and you would cut your hands before you could break the string.
This camera...
It was very successful.
And during the several months we had it, it took a great many pictures and was really, I think, the forerunner of cameras that were to be used at deeper than diver depths.
And it showed that it was really nothing very difficult about it.
And as we emphasized in the paper,
Ewing and Warzel and I wrote.
It was not a question of optics.

It was a question of mechanics, of arranging your equipment so that there would be something in front of the camera when you took the picture, and then also in not violating the simple elementary rules of backlighting and so forth.
The National Geographic then sponsored us for
more comprehensive photographic program which we made a camera to operate on the bottom of the ocean out to depths of three miles.
This camera was one of the first pieces of equipment we lowered without any wires or cables.
And if I might just tell a sea story
There, many years later, I was honored by the Compass Award of the Marine Technology Society.

And when given the award, normally one says as little as possible, but I made a comment that when the man was outlining all of the splendid things I was supposed to have done, that all I could think of was when we took our deep sea camera out for the first time.
And in that clear, azure water off Bermuda, we lowered it over the side and cast it free.
And when it was about 10 feet underwater, I remembered I had left the lens cap on.
And nothing could have been further from your mind that you would ever be given any kind of an award for anything other than nautical ignorance.
